newsitem.title: USA: US Treasury cites progress fighting counterfeiting.
newsitem.headline: US Treasury cites progress fighting counterfeiting.

text.p: Treasury officials said on Thursday they have made progress in the fight against counterfeiters with the new, high security $100 bill that has proved impossible to match -- so far.
The bills, introduced in March, 1996, have sophisticated protections against high tech counterfeiting.

"We have found that the security features have performed as expected and to date, the Secret Service has found no counterfeit Series 1996 notes it would characterise as highly deceptive," Treasury Undersecretary John Hawke Jr. told the House Banking and Financial Services Subcommittee on general oversight and investigations.

Hawke said that just 3.4 percent of all counterfeit notes passed to the public attempt to imitate the new $100 bill. He said the main problem has been that in many cases people do not yet know what the new bills look like, so they have nothing to compare.

The new bills have a large, off-centre picture of Benjamin Franklin to make space for a special watermark embedded in the paper. They also use colour-shifting ink, plastic security threads that glow in ultraviolet light and microprinting of the letters "USA."
The Treasury also passed around samples of a new $50 bill -- not yet in circulation -- for members of the committee to examine.
But the committee remained concerned that the Treasury must do more to fight counterfeiting, especially abroad.

The congressional investigating arm, the General Accounting Office, has issued a series of reports charging that the Treasury has fallen short in carrying out anti-counterfeiting provisions in federal law.

"The secretary of the Treasury's submitted plan does not demonstrate how it will enable the Treasury to meet the audit plan objectives required under the Act," a recent GAO report cited by Committee Chairman Spencer Bachus, an Alabama Republican said.

Bachus, author of a law requiring Treasury to redouble its efforts to track counterfeiting abroad, told the department officials: "There is some reason for concern ... that the Treasury Department may not be taking this statutory mandate seriously."
Treasury Deputy Assistant Secretary for Federal Finance Roger Anderson replied that the administration was improving its oversight of U.S. currency circulating abroad.
"We are now focusing more on the uses of U.S. currency and the quantities of genuine and counterfeit U.S. currency that are in circulation around the world," he said.
